Comment: I've been experimenting with the Kramnik-like openings recently, especially against stronger players, as I find that the more direct Kingside openings don't wrk so well against them.
A sort of King's Indian Attack type move, freeing the other bishop, covering e4 and c4, preparing either Pe4 or Pc4 and preventing Black from playing ... Ne4

Black has a flexible Semi-Slav-type position.  We're both skirting around each other at present.

I try to avoid automatically pushing a bishop away because the rook's pawn often becomes vulnerable to a battery by Q and B, but as I want to play e4, I want to release the potential pin first.  If ...Bh5, I'll probably play g4.  If ..Bf5 or ...Be6 I've achieved my objective and have plenty of potential on e4.  If ...Bxf3, I get the bishop pair.
Now I can't play e4 immediately because the Bg6, Nf6 and Pd5 outnumber my supporting pieces on d3 and d2.  So I harrass the B again.

not sure who this swap favours more.  If I'd retaken with the pawn, the N would still have blocked my B in, so I preferred to use the N first.  Black now frees his Q to attack on that h-file though...

OK - maybe not: the N replaces its dead brother and maintains the pressure on e4, meanwhile potentially opening the d-file to the Q's influence

so, naturally, I pin it.  This is no longer as risky as it would have been had Black's h pawn still been in situ.  I normally try to avoid developing a B long in front of a fianchettoed B because of its restricted scope for escape.
not releasing the pin, but preparing Q-side castling to take advantage of the h file and maintaining the major piece defence of the Nf6
preparing to contest the d file with the rooks, while also over-defending e4 and looking at the Q-side for future attacks when Black castles
further preparation for the Q-side attack.  The b-pawn needs support.
further preparation for the Q-side attack.  The b-pawn needs support.
revealing the attack on the Q while attacking f2
lining up the B with the K and making the b-pawn's advance more threatening
releasing the pin and over-defending c6.  The immediate threat is 20...Nxe4, forking Q and B

the only safe place that doesn't obstruct other pieces or risk some other positional disadvantage (20. Be3 Bxe3).  I preserve the B pair and prepare to disturb the N, constraining the K-side pawns.
preparing to mobilise the K-side pawns

oh yes, the planned advance... Do I forget that g5 would inhibit the K-side pawn advance or just revert to plan A, launching an unsubtle attack on the castled king.  I don't remember... What I like about positions like this is that battle is engaged across the whole front.   Attack and defence have to be mixed judiciously.  The initiative is worth several pawns...
